um work that we've supported you can come by the booze Allen booth or or tomorrow we'll actually be giving a uh

like to uh introduce uh CJ and Jen Thank you Thanks So I'm Jen Gray and I
work with Amazon Web Services Security Assurance and Compliance Program I oversee our North America public sector
programs um which include our Fed Ramp DoD state and local government regula
regulations Um so today we're really excited to have CJ here for our fireside chat Um I have some really great

security services that are available for customers today So we're going to get right into the CJ Okay CJ you're the deputy chief
information security officer for AWS By introduction can you perhaps tell a
history about what brought you to AWS and the types of things you do today sure Sure Glad to So um my story goes
back a little bit over 10 years Uh about 10 years ago um myself and actually our
siz um and a handful of others that are part of the security organization at AWS Uh we were running an organization
within the FBI um that organization was responsible for um every piece of
digital media that came into the US government went through this agency so that we could cross-correlate it against
um uh other things that we had had um for counterterrorism purposes Um and as you can imagine uh it's a pretty
stressful job trying to find the needles in the needle stack Um as part of that what we had to do is we had to continue
to build bigger better um you know more uh efficient data centers uh in order to
do that and over a few years we did exactly that I think we were on our fifth generation of the data center or
the data centers um uh about the time that we started looking for other technologies So we sent our chief
engineer and a couple others out to the out to the left coast uh the west coast where all the technology is um or at
least that's where we thought it all was and it turned out to be true Um many of the providers uh that we spoke to out
there were willing to sell us more hardware and more software Um unfortunately we had a lot of that Um
and what we were looking for was new technology Um but one company um that uh
you know uh we spoke with or that our team spoke with um seemed to have the
technology but didn't uh really have the wherewithal to understand how to deal with the federal government much less um
the environment that we were coming from and a highly classified one Um but they
turned out to be a lot better salespeople than we were uh over the course of 6 or 8 months thereafter
rather than um us talking them into building this capability for the government um so that we could actually
use elastic scaling and things like that They talked a handful of us into coming to work for AWS So uh the beginnings of
what became AWS security a few years later um started by us you know the the
handful of us at the FBI needing the capability um that AWS provided the
elastic scaling capability to be able to scale up many thousands of instances you know at Friday on Friday at 4:30 when
invariably the truck with many hard drives would show up and there would be one piece of data one needle in that
needle stack that would you know keep bad things from happening to good people um AWS was the the company that had that
technology um and using that kind of uh persuasion They talked us into uh to
coming on board such that someday we would be able to provide that capability uh back to the government uh so that we
can keep you know bad things from happening to good people So uh that was 10 years ago It seems like it was
yesterday literally flew by So rather than holding the one big
questions toward the end I thought we'd jump right into it How many customers that I speak to um constantly ask me
um what does your security what does your security leadership think about like what keeps you up at night
so normally it's my dog or my daughter but um uh no seriously I don't think you
guys care about that part I I think the one thing that um over time that's uh that's come out is um that customers
don't understand our shared security responsibility model Um that's something that you know early on uh you know going
back say I guess 8 years or something like that maybe nine Um one of the things that uh I was made responsible
for is taking all the questions that we regularly get from customers and co coallesing them into a document um that
ultimately could be shared with customers so that they would get the answers to those questions Started out almost as a frequently asked questions
type of doc and then turned into a security white paper Uh still exists in a many many more pages version today Um
but I think as we were going from the first to the second version of that um we started having this epiphany I don't
know if you'll call it that um customers weren't sure as to what
their responsibilities were in the cloud um was it that you put stuff in the cloud and AWS took care of everything or
was it that they still were responsible for things so the idea of a shared responsibility model or a shared
security responsibility model um was introduced at that point to make sure we could explain that and how this this
model works The easiest way that I explain it and it may not be that easy but we'll see um is
that that which you as a customer have access to you have some responsibility for Um and that includes in the security
space Um so in my case if I'm you know on the AWS side from the concrete of the
data center floor all the way up to we'll say for in the case of EC2 up to you know the hypervisor of that instance
is my responsibility You have no access to it Therefore we shouldn't hold you accountable for any of the security
protocols and procedures that go along with that That's that's on us Um and that is our responsibility and that's
you know security of the cloud Um th then customers have responsibility for
those things above that in in some cases that which you have access to when you start up a new EC2 instance um and you
do your your exchange and now you have sole access to that that EC2 instance
You've gone ahead and set up your security groups You now have this instance At that point we're not in a position to be able to do security on
that because you now have the only access to it We can't do patching or other types of things for you Why this
keeps me up at night is exactly that If customers don't understand that once they've launched these instances that
they have responsibility to patch them you can be in a situation where you have unpatched virtual machines that are
running in the cloud Um that when something like wry or something like that those types of exploits come up
come up Um then you have these instances that potentially can be had um and um
that's not a good customer experience Some of the things we do up front to try to prevent that is you know every
instance that you launch those virtual machines comes up with a default deny all firewall meaning we're blocking
everything unless you open it up That's what a security group is and is an allowance list It's an list to allow you
into or allow whatever you choose into that instance Um in the case of W to Cry
um by default you know SMB would be would be blocked unless you chose to
open it And we did have customers that chose to open it and didn't patch properly and therefore had had issues
And we do everything that we can in order to support them make notifications when we see these this type of activity
that's indicative of these types of things Um but really th that's the kind of thing that we we continually run into
Um one of the other things just real briefly I don't want to go too long because I know we have many more questions to go through but one of the
other parts there is that we've we've also seen not only the wicry type of things from an EC2 perspective um where
you know we've had these situations um our our storage service S3 um even RDS
and Elastic Search um many times when you initiate or you place data you have
the choice of what the privilege is or what the you know access controls are on that Once again it'll default down to no
access and then it increases and you can adjust it by policy or otherwise in order to uh to open it up more so
depending on your needs And we do have the ability for you to open it up worldwide to the internet Not
recommended but still there because sometimes that is actually what customers want and need So what we
really uh what we see or have seen is that people will take advantage of you opening things up and leaving it out
there for others for everyone to see And we've seen more of that in the ransomware type of space where if you
open something up and put it out there um some you know someone uh with nefarious intentions will go ahead and
either delete it and then put a note in there saying we've we've encrypted your data and if you want it back pay us
we've seen a rash of that So we have as much as we can proactively try to assist in those cases But um it is one of the
things that you know if you say what keeps me up at night um in that space that's uh that's probably uh the one
thing is making sure customers realize there are some things that are their responsibility still and that they
should make sure as they're working through into the cloud that they understand what those things are and we
are are here to help you It's not as if we're leaving you out there in the dark We have tools and other things that I'm sure we'll have a chance to talk about
as we go on Right So you mentioned about the wannquer want to cry ransomware and you
described the shared security responsibility model Um does AWS you talked a little bit you touched on how
AWS um helps customers with that Um but does AWS help customers even though the
responsibility lies with them so yeah absolutely So we have you know if if you
look at you know our pace of innovation over the years um which just you know
from a security perspective you would think is uh um you know crazy to try to keep up with Last year we launched uh
just over a thousand uh features or large uh services or large features um
and about a third actually I think it was almost 37% of those were security
security or compliance in nature So we're always trying to up the bar
provide better capabilities to you to take away that undifferiated heavy lifting I'm sure you've heard so much
about in the last few days Um in doing so in the security space as well um we
continue to offer more services and capabilities um in order to make it easier for you to operate or to secure
in in the cloud itself um you know some of the things that um we have various different services that
uh have come out just just to help you in that case Um EC2 systems manager um
is one that actually would help you in some of the uh some of the wicry or some of these other situations to make sure

security that comes up frequently yeah So cost should never be a barrier uh to
you know having a secure cloud environment A lot of the things I just tal talked about cost nothing you get

it's uh you there's no additional cost in that space Um many of the services that we have that we you know if you

service and capability that the team that came over from the FBI created So we created this virtual private cloud
environment because um if you think about it um you know coming from the
government we wanted to be able to slice off a piece of the cloud and use it for our own purposes So what BPC is is a
logical a logical isolation um of the cloud So a logical network isolation um
and allows you to have an enclave within that cloud environment that you carry your own IP addressing to So obviously
from a networking perspective and otherwise it's it's isolated So when we're um looking at it from that
perspective you can actually you know create these environments have that isolation and do so for very little
money if if at any if at any cost at all So um you know from that standpoint the
features that we launch in the security space are intentionally designed around trying to make sure you have a good

to our government customers is they have a lot of questions about what AWS does I
cover the compliance programs in our North America region and um one key
topic that comes up is the supply chain risk management How does AWS think about and address
this topic so this is an interesting one and we could have you know a several day
dissertation going on here So I'm not going to hit on all the points but literally um we
have we'll split it into two kind of general areas Um because supply chain
which used to be and for many of us coming from the Department of Defense or uh that that background you always think
supply chain it's always hard things you know your literal um hardware uh things
of that nature Um but that's not necessarily the case in in newer environments because the software and
the things that that software are part of are just as much uh a part of that supply chain So I'll split it into two
So from a hardware perspective um we're we're blessed with having uh the ability
and scale uh to operate at at very in large very large quantities um that
allows us um also the ability to uh to have many suppliers It also allows us
the ability to uh design and create our own hardware And when I say hardware I'm going to use it generically for firmware
and all the other pieces and parts that lead up to that Um so in that space it allows us all of this capability um that
uh um makes it very much more difficult u from a uh you know from a supply chain
uh environment to to target it Um you may think oh many suppliers that means you're uh you have many different
avenues in um you would think that but the thing is is that every one of our suppliers is actually supplying us with
things that we specified We've qualified upfront and we know exactly what it is
Meaning that in many cases our own intellectual property is being licensed out to these providers in order to be
able to sell us stuff as well as our own contract manufacturers or our own people
So we we have this process in place that allows us to to know what it's supposed to be and what it's supposed to do
because in many cases we've engineered it we've designed it um as part of that qualification that starts up early Then
following on behind that whenever we receive things we have an entire process that we go through that includes um
verifying that to make sure that it is what it's supposed to be And how we do that is in many cases via softwarebased
So we'll actually go through um the the first thing we do which you know many of
you will probably understand is that we don't trust what we get We uh we reflash
everything from scratch So everything comes in regardless of what it may be and it gets built from the ground up Um
and then it goes into a burn burn-in period of time and once that's up and running you're in a situation where you
have a known true good and then you can work from there um you know uh from a
you know from my past life you know I was a computer crime investigator and you know worked in various space uh one
of the things in counter intelligence trying to keep people from spying on us or if they were to catch them and in
that space one of the things that they would you know intentionally do these adversaries is they would have to target
they would have to figure out where is the hardware going to be so that we can put an implant on it and that way it'll
end up being in this this entity so we can get data from them Uh the scale that
I was speaking of earlier allows us um a great obuscation layer meaning that it's
very difficult to be able to target whose data where how what if you were to even try to go into that space Not
saying it's impossible but we definitely have a lot of those things in place and many others that I'm not actually going
to to speak to you about today Um let me go on to software
Um so from a software perspective um we have um a very robust application
security process um you know uh they we get into a situation where
um if you're a lot of new new uh environments are starting to talk about
DevOps and um you many of you are probably moving towards a DevOps type of
environment and one of the things that DevOps gives you is the ability to innovate and to um to uh to move very
quickly um as well as many of the other benefits that come along with it One of the things that um it it uh causes a
little bit of of turn on is that if you use your old security environment um in
the way that you traditionally had what what you're going to miss is that you're going to go very go down to the very end
and you're um going to build all this software and your developers are going to you know push it on and normally
you're going to have some sort of testing at the end and that testing at the end traditionally your apps or
pentest groups um are going to be the ones was trying to find those things that were built into the process So what
we do and how we do it differently is we have our teams do sec DevOps or dev sec
ops however you want to put it but I I'll go with SEC DevOps And that is is that iteratively is part of the process
both we the security team as well as the developers themselves and um iterate as
they go along Um an example of this um in some of the tooling going back to some of the earlier discussion we were
talking about that we have that allows us to to help in the space is using things like Amazon Inspector um in order
to do iterative looks at the the code or much more than the code the the actual a uh machine image um that these things
are being run on And what this does is allows you to iteratively throughout the process find those failures faults and
issues And when you're finding them closer to when you created them the engineers themselves can fix them
So where I'm going with all of this is that we spend tens of millions of dollars on application security and
pentesters every year um for all of those services and features that we you know we push forward to you And in that
process one of the things that in that model what we've done is we've changed it up so that we're not doing just pen
penetration testing for those of you that aren't familiar right at the end We're actually having engagements that
start from the beginning because security the security group should not be a a group of no And if your security
team is the group of no you've got the wrong security team Security should be an enabler Therefore we should be part
of the process and the engineering all the way through And when it comes to software from a supply chain perspective
what we're doing is trying to make sure that we have the strongest ca strongest capability all the way through that process um which on the outside of on
the back side of that means that when we do do penetration testing um the results that we get um aren't lowhanging fruit
or easy things to get they are things that are very difficult and those are the types of things we want to find when
we're doing and spending uh the amount of time and effort that we do in that space So another question that we hear
from our public sector customers it's a key security topic is insider threat
What would you tell someone in the audience who's thinking about moving to cloud computing um when they start
moving to that environment of no longer having that full control over their environment
well the well I could ask them a question back Um but um rather than
making it a question I'll make it a statement And that is that one of the things that we've realized especially
operating in a cloud environment is that um if you have individuals that have
both physical and logical access meaning they had can physically touch the servers as well as log onto them and see
what's on them um you now have an inadequate level of uh separation of
duties One of the tenants that we have from AWS across the board is that um if
you have logical access say you're a data tech in a data center you shall not have logical access meaning you cannot
log on to that system or those systems that are within that space What does this do we talked a minute ago about
targeting If you're unable to target or identify what's where it makes it very difficult for you to determine um you
know what you're after or what you know if you're actually after something you won't know where it is um this
obfuscation or this inability for people that are physically within the environment to be able to see what is
there and who's the customer and all of that type of data um makes it much less
you know appealing for them to do anything with it We have many controls that back back that up from the
standpoint of you know we talk about hard drives Hard drives or any storage devices don't leave our environment
without being mulched um or otherwise destroyed in a physical manner where
which the people that are guarding the facility can tell So if a hard drive leaves intact you know that's not not a
good thing The hard drive leaves mulched into little pieces that's the way it's supposed to be Um let me see there's
some other things One of one of the things the biggest thing that I'll say is and I've got kind of two I think Um
one is is that we take uh um goals every year across our organization and one of
the goals that we've taken and we've pushed I should say from a security environment is that year over year we've
pushed the teams to decrease human access or the ability for a human to
access customer data by 80% Year over year over year What is that doing if I
tell you you know you're you're running an environment and I say decrease the amount of humans uh they have access to
the data by 10% You're going to cut 10% of the staff that has access to that Just remove them from it and that's easy
What uh security value have you added probably very little If I tell you you have to remove 80% of the staff that has
access to that data you're going to be forced to innovate You're going to be forced to create tooling that allows them access only to that specific thing
that they need to have access to and maybe only for a short period of time the time that they need it And if you do
that year after year after year guess what happens you you narrow the large scope of potential for insider threat or
insider actors down more and more and more and more So this is the type of thing that you know that you need to you
know even with your in your own organizations if you're trying to figure out how to decrease that threat the
threat vector or the risk that's how you do it You do things like like that This
one other quick thing and I'll cognitive of time and we'll tell you as much as we
can but the other thing that we do is from an insider threat perspective is we're huge on automation and that is
that we love metrics within our company We love data Whenever you can you know
work with data you know you're in a good position because you're going to be able to distill that data down to um things
that you can actually take action on So as you might imagine we have millions and millions of logs and other things
that are floating around or being generated by all of your use of the cloud environments And what we're
actually doing is we're doing analysis of of those accesses from our internal people looking for things that are
aberritions to the norm those aberitions to the norm whatever they may be because we've learned over time by looking
through that data We've created automations that will alert a human
whenever one of those aberitions pops up And that'll go to the security operations team that uh that works for
me And they will actually look into each and every occurrence that's brought forward And guess what we have a
feedback loop between what they find there to make the automations better or to create new ones New things pop up we
actually add new new things you think you're probably thinking oh this is a signaturebased analysis It can't be only
signature based because of the scale that we operate on So we're looking for aberitions Those may be things where
traffic spikes too high or traffic's too low not just you know individual little
things uh or signatures that you may be looking for Signatures will fail over time You need to be looking at the the
uh the uh the changes uh or the things that are out of out of the norm
So I'd like to dive deep a little bit on the automation piece that you spoke about Customers have told us that you

in indications whether ind indications of compromise or threat intel that's created out of that are things that you

know one of the things that I'll say you can increase security by getting rid of humans but obviously to some point you
you have to have some humans involved Um the other thing is is we we we continue
to get the question about you know we talked you know you brought up the uh you know there's got to be humans security operations team on on the back

uh you know from from that standpoint you take it kind of a a step forward Um and um people can't see the data center
so they want to see our sock or security operations center because I know when I was at the FBI one of the things we built was an awesome sock It was like
spaceship enterprise the bridge It was great We had lots of screens and stuff like that But one of the things I
learned and that we've learned you know over the years even at AWS is that who's in that sock at 2 a.m that's answering
the phone and what are they able to do turns into kind of a call center There's a phone to call So there's
somebody there That's great But what capable you know what capability do they have normally it's very hard to staff at
2 am with the brightest minds or the people that know the exact details that you need So we've kind of taken it uh
you know a step to become a virtual sock Our software we've created with those
indications and those looking for these aberitions and made the software smart enough in order to when anything is out
of sorts it calls us It pages us And not only does it pages us through the
ticketing system so that we we can maintain state on everything Um as part of that it then creates almost a
crowdsourced response from all of those entities that have something to do with that particular issue that's been
brought up So if it's networking based obviously calls in the networking people If it's a certain service it'll call
them in And uh from there then you have the ability to have real experts that
are on call that are responding to in near real time or within 5 minutes normally on average uh to be able to
interject and figure out what the issues are So rather than spending money and this is just coming from me you take it
with a grain of salt Rather than spending money on that big enterprise thing spend it on making sure that
everybody has uh you know good laptops VPNs and things like that in order to be able to log in and figure out to look at

uh resolution environments is what we'll actually do is we'll go ahead and as you
jump on the call whatever service or entity you're representing you've checked your dashboard to see whether
you're the respons you have a response to what's going on and then to try to prove that you aren't the reason for
it Not the inverse Don't come on and start pointing fingers It's literally everybody has to prove or has to bring
forward nope my service looks good All of my metrics are the same as they should be The ones that say no could
either be you know the cause or they could be part of the effect So that's
the type of mentality So once again going back to kind of the question um we automate everything we possibly can
